{{Infobox organization | type = [[Intergovernmental organisation]] | key_people = Rolf Luyendijk, Executive Director
[[Amina J. Mohammed]], former Chair and current Deputy Secretary General of the United Nations | name = Water Supply and Sanitation Collaborative Council | location_city = [[Geneva]] | location_country = [[Switzerland]] | location = | area_served = Worldwide, with particular focus on Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia | origins = | focus = [[Sanitation]], [[hygiene]], [[water supply]] | website = {{URL|wsscc.org}} }} {{Infobox |name = Infobox/doc |bodystyle = |title = |titlestyle = |image = |imagestyle = |caption = |captionstyle = |headerstyle = background:#ccf; |labelstyle = background:#ddf; |datastyle = |header1 = Vision and Mission |label1 = Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All |data3 = The Water Supply and Sanitation Collaborative Council's vision is of a world where everybody has sustained water supply, sanitation and hygiene. }} The '''Water Supply and Sanitation Collaborative Council''' ('''WSSCC''') is a [[United Nations]] membership organization that advocates for improved [[sanitation]] and [[hygiene]] for the most vulnerable and marginalized people around the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.globalcitizen.org/en/partners/wsscc/ |title=About WSSCC |publisher=Global Citizen |date= |accessdate=2015-12-17}} WSSCC facilitates multi-stakeholder collaboration around sanitation and contributes to the [[international community]]'s broader goals of poverty eradication, health and environmental improvement, gender equality and long-term social and economic development.{{cite web|url=http://www.gwp.org/en/Our-approach/Strategic-Allies/WSSCC/ |title=Water Supply and Sanitation Collaborative Council (WSSCC) |publisher=Global Water Partnership |date= |accessdate=2015-12-17}} WSSCC's main areas of focus are large-scale sanitation and hygiene [[Behavior change (public health)|behaviour change]] programmes through the [[Global Sanitation Fund]] -promoting sanitation and hygiene as the gateway to inclusion and opportunity; and bringing together leaders and activists to strengthen the global sanitation movement. WSSCC's members and staff lobbied for a [[Sustainable Development Goals|Sustainable Development Goal]] target for sanitation and hygiene. WSSCC contributes measurably to the achievement of SDG 6.2: ''By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.'' ==Scope== WSSCC works to address the [[sanitation]] crisis and promote universal access to sanitation in collaboration with a range of partners.{{cite web|url=http://www.ids.ac.uk/news/world-water-day-2013-ensuring-universal-access-to-water-and-sanitation |title=World Water Day 2013: Ensuring universal access to water and sanitation |publisher=Institute of Development Studies |date= |accessdate=2015-12-17}} The [[United Nations]] estimates that 2.3 billion people live without access to safe sanitation.{{cite web|url=http://www.wssinfo.org/fileadmin/user_upload/resources/JMP-Update-report-2015_English.pdf |title=Progress on Sanitation and Drinking Water 2015 Update and MDG Assessment |publisher=WHO/UNICEF |date= |accessdate=2015-12-17}} According to the [[World Bank]], poor sanitation costs countries approximately $260 billion annually.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsp.org/content/economic-impacts-sanitation |title=Economics of Sanitation Initiative |publisher=Water and Sanitation Program |date= |accessdate=2015-12-17}} WSSCC addresses a range of sanitation and [[hygiene]]-related issues within its focus areas such as: * identifying financial and human resources gaps{{Cite web|url = http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2014/water-sanitation/en/|title = "UN reveals major gaps in water and sanitation – especially in rural areas". World Health Organization. Retrieved 8 January 2016.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} and overhauling financing for development{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/chris-w-williams/can-we-finance-sustainabl_b_7784346.html|title = "Can We Finance Sustainable Development?". The Huffington Post. Retrieved 8 January 2016.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} in support of the [[Sustainable Development Goals]];{{Cite web|url = http://www.irinnews.org/report/98702/analysis-debating-the-best-way-to-improve-water-and-sanitation-post-mdgs|title = "Analysis: Debating the best way to improve water and sanitation post-MDGs". IRIN. Retrieved 8 January 2016.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} * addressing issues (bottlenecks) that are slowing down implementation of sanitation systems;{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/nov/19/water-sanitation-target-development-goals-un|title = "Water target least on-track among all development goals, UN says". The Guardian. Retrieved 8 January 2016.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} * highlighting the connection between sanitation and human dignity, health, education, community empowerment{{Cite web|title = Soon, there will be a perfume strong enough to counter stinky loos in India and Africa|url = http://qz.com/423192/finally-scientists-have-created-a-perfume-strong-enough-to-counter-stinky-indian-loos/|website = Quartz|accessdate = 2015-12-28|language = en-US}}{{Cite web|title = Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) is more than just toilets|url = https://www.theguardian.com/wsscc-partner-zone/2015/oct/19/community-led-total-sanitation-clts-is-more-than-just-toilets|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-12-28|first = Elizabeth|last = Wamera}} and business.{{Cite news|title = Sustainable Development: sanitation needs more private investment|url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/b899d272-5090-11e5-8642-453585f2cfcd.html#axzz3veB1mddL|newspaper = Financial Times|date = 2015-09-15|access-date = 2015-12-28|issn = 0307-1766|first = Sarah|last = Murray}}{{Cite web|title = "World Toilet Day" No Joke for Billions Without Sanitation {{!}} Inter Press Service|url = http://www.ipsnews.net/2013/11/world-toilet-day-no-joke-for-billions-without-sanitation/|website = www.ipsnews.net|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} == Activities == WSSCC collaborates with government agencies, non-governmental organizations, international organizations, [[civil society]] groups and the private sector internationally and at the national, regional and local levels. Key collaborating partners include [[WaterAid]], the [http://sanitationandwaterforall.org Sanitation and Water For All], and [[UNICEF]], among others. The organization also advocates around key sanitation and hygiene international days such as [[World Toilet Day]]{{Cite web|title = Tapping into the Power of the Toilet|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/chris-w-williams/tapping-the-power-of-the-toilet_b_8592332.html|website = The Huffington Post|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} and [[Global Handwashing Day]].{{Cite journal|title = Not Just Another Day|url = https://www.theguardian.com/wsscc-partner-zone/2015/oct/15/not-just-another-day|journal = The Guardian|date = 2015-10-15}} === Global Sanitation Fund === {{Main|Global Sanitation Fund}} Through the [[Global Sanitation Fund|Global Sanitation Fund (GSF)]], a multi-donor United Nations [[trust fund]], WSSCC supports national efforts to help rural communities improve their sanitation and adopt good hygiene practices. The GSF funds behaviour change activities. [[Community-led total sanitation]] is frequently utilized by GSF-funded national programmes, such as in Cambodia{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/eapro/Community_Led_Total_Sanitation.pdf |title=Community-Led Total Sanitation in East Asia and Pacific |publisher=UNICEF |date= |accessdate=2016-01-08}} and Nigeria.{{Cite web|title = Women show the way in water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH)|url = http://www.trust.org/item/20140320171632-1j6lw/|website = Thomson Reuters Foundation|accessdate = 2016-01-08}} The GSF currently funds national programmes in [[Benin]], [[Cambodia]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Kenya]], [[Madagascar]], [[Malawi]], [[Nepal]], [[Nigeria]], [[Senegal]], [[Tanzania]], [[Togo]] and [[Uganda]]. WSSCC's Secretariat gathers funds and donations at the global level, selects the eligible countries for funding, and manages the disbursement of grants to national sanitation programmes. === Equality and non-discrimination === WSSCC advocates for equality, [[Right to water|human rights]] and non-discrimination as central to ensuring access to safe water supply, adequate sanitation and good hygiene for all. In particular, WSSCC WASH advocates promote women's participation and leadership{{Cite web|title = Women Show the Way in Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH)|url = http://www.trust.org/item/20140320171632-1j6lw/|website = Thomson Reuters Foundation|accessdate = 2016-01-08}} and menstrual hygiene management.{{Cite web|title = The invention that aims to make periods less of a pain|url = https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/oct/02/menstruation-flo-periods-less-of-a-pain-for-girls-asia-africa/|website = The Guardian|accessdate = 2016-01-08}}{{Cite web|title = Disposable tampons aren't sustainable, but do women want to talk about it?|url = https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/apr/27/disposable-tampons-arent-sustainable-but-do-women-want-to-talk-about-it|website = The Guardian|accessdate = 2016-01-08}}{{Cite web|title = No Menstrual Hygiene For Indian Women Holds Economy Back|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-07-24/no-menstrual-hygiene-for-indian-women-holds-economy-back|website = Bloomberg|accessdate = 2016-01-08}} === Menstrual hygiene management === A key challenge that WSSCC is addressing relates to the inclusion of [[Menstrual hygiene day|menstrual hygiene management]] in the sustainable development agenda. WSSCC has highlighted that the [[Menstrual taboo|taboo]] surrounding [[menstruation]] is a barrier to equal participation and opportunities for women.{{Cite web|title = Opinion: Let’s Talk Menstruation. Period|url = http://www.ipsnews.net/2015/05/opinion-lets-talk-menstruation-period/|website = Inter Press Service|accessdate = 2016-01-08}} A [[National Public Radio]] article{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2015/09/25/443103720/trying-to-add-the-m-word-menstruation-to-the-u-n-s-new-goals |title=Trying To Add The 'M' Word (Menstruation) To The U.N.'s New Goals |publisher=NPR|date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} highlighted that many policy makers often admit that they had never considered questions around menstruation before. === Other focus areas === Operationally, sustaining behaviour change as well as ensuring reliable and consistent monitoring have been identified as challenges. Of particular note is the challenge related to monitoring households that return to previous unhygienic behaviours. WSSCC and its partners are addressing these issues through systems strengthening{{cite web|url=http://wsscc.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Mada-15.pdf |title=Learning, progress and innovation: Sanitation and hygiene promotion in Madagascar |publisher=WSSCC |date= |accessdate=2015-12-19}} and [[impact evaluation]]s.{{cite web|url=http://wsscc.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Evidence-Programme-on-Sanitation-and-Hygiene-web.pdf |title=The Evidence Programme on Sanitation and Hygiene |publisher=WSSCC |date= |accessdate=2015-12-19}} === Reports and campaigns === Notable reports and campaigns supported by WSSCC include: * 'We Can't Wait', a report on sanitation and hygiene for women and girls produced in collaboration with WaterAid and [[Unilever]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wateraid.org/what-we-do/our-approach/research-and-publications/view-publication?id=a5ab0a96-1574-4225-a16a-75d5e5ec4232 |title=We Can't Wait |publisher=WaterAid, Unilever, WSSCC |date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} * The Global Water Supply and Sanitation Assessment report produced in collaboration with the WHO and UNICEF{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2014/water-sanitation/en/ |title=UN reveals major gaps in water and sanitation – especially in rural areas |publisher=WHO |date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} * The United Nations 'End Open Defecation' campaign{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/millenniumgoals/endopendefecation.shtml |title=Breaking the silence on open defecation |publisher=United Nations|date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} * The Women for Water and Sanitation Declaration, sanctioned by the first ladies of Madagascar and Malawi, among others{{cite web|url=https://www.globalcitizen.org/en/content/women-for-water-and-sanitation-declaration/ |title=Women for water and sanitation declaration |publisher=Global Poverty Project|date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} ==Organizational structure== WSSCC is administratively and legally hosted by UNOPS. The WSSCC Secretariat is governed by the WSSCC Steering Committee, and has three main departments: (i) Networking and Knowledge Management; (ii) [[Advocacy]] and Communications; (iii) the GSF.{{cite web|url=http://wsscc.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/global_sanitation_fund_progress_report_2014_web.pdf |title=Global Sanitation Fund Progress Report 2014 |publisher=WSSCC. p. 54 |date= |accessdate=2015-12-19}} The WSSCC Steering Committee decides the policies and strategies of the organization, manages the governance process, and is accountable to both the membership and the donors for its work. It is made up of a chair, regional members, partner agency members, ex officio members, non-voting invitees, and permanent non-voting observers. All WSSCC members are eligible to stand and vote in elections for the Steering Committee. The interim Chairs are Brad Herbert and Ebele Okeke, who have been in post since November 2016. Previous Chairs were: [[Anna Tibaijuka]], 2011-2015; Roberto Lenton, 2005 – 2011; Sir [[Richard Jolly]], 1997 – 2004; and [[Margaret Catley-Carlson]], 1990 – 1996. [[Amina J. Mohammed]], Deputy Secretary-General of the United Nations and former Minister of Environment of Nigeria, served as WSSCC's Chair{{cite web|url=http://newsghana.com.gh/amina-mohammed-to-chair-leading-wash-organization/ |title=Amina Mohammed to Chair Leading WASH Organization |publisher=News Ghana |date=2016-01-19 |accessdate=2016-01-19}} from April 2016 to November 2016. The Secretariat’s Executive Director is Rolf Luyendijk, who will join WSSCC from UNICEF in March 2018. WSSCC’s secretariat is headquartered in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. ===Funding=== The organization currently receives or has received funding from seven governments: [[Australia]],{{cite web|url=http://dfat.gov.au/aid/Pages/australias-aid-program.aspx |title=Australia's Aid Program |publisher=Australian Government Department of foreign Affairs and Trade |date= |accessdate=2015-12-19}} [[Finland]],{{cite web|url=http://formin.finland.fi/public/default.aspx?nodeid=49273&contentlan=2&culture=en-US |title=Developmental Policy and Developmental Cooperation |publisher=Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland |date= |accessdate=2015-12-19}} the [[Netherlands]],{{cite web|url=https://www.government.nl/ministries/ministry-of-foreign-affairs#ref-minbuza |title=Ministry of Foreign Affairs |publisher=Government of the Netherlands |date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} [[Norway]], [[Sweden]],{{cite web|url=http://www.sida.se/English/ |title=Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency |publisher=Government of Sweden |date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} [[Switzerland]],{{cite web|url=https://www.eda.admin.ch/sdc |title=Development and Cooperation |publisher=Government of Switzerland|date= |accessdate=2015-12-30}} and the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/department-for-international-development |title=Department for International Development |publisher=Government of the United Kingdom|date= |accessdate=2016-01-08}} == History == In 1990, a group of senior staff of developing country governments, [[wikt:bilateral|bilateral]] and multilateral agencies, [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]] and research institutions founded WSSCC. On December 21, 1990, the 45th Session of the UN General Assembly elected to pass resolution A/RES/45/181,{{Cite web|url = https://www.un.org/documents/ga/res/45/a45r181.htm|title = A/RES/45/181. International Drinking Water Supply and Sanitation Decade|date = |accessdate = 2015-12-17|website = |publisher = UN.org|last = |first = }} which emphasized the “importance of intensifying the coordination of national activities undertaken with the assistance of all relevant agencies in the field of water supply and sanitation through, in particular, the inter-agency Steering Committee for Co-operative Action for the International Drinking Water Decade and the Water Supply and Sanitation Collaborative Council”. Through this resolution the WSSCC was formally established as an independent organization with a United Nations mandate. During the 1990s, WSSCC concentrated on sharing knowledge and convening thematic discussion groups on water- and sanitation-related topics. In 2000, WSSCC published Vision 21,{{Cite web|url = http://www.ircwash.org/sites/default/files/WSSCC-2000-Vision.pdf|title = Vision 21: A Shared Vision for Hygiene, Sanitation and Water Supply and a Framework for Action|date = |accessdate = 2015-12-17|website = |publisher = IRC|last = |first = }} a proposal for achieving universal water, sanitation and hygiene coverage. WSSCC is an unincorporated membership organization and not a separate legal entity. From 1991 to 2009, it was hosted by the [[World Health Organization|World Health Organization (WHO)]]. Since 2010, WSSCC has been hosted by the [[United Nations Office for Project Services|United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS)]].{{Cite web|url = http://reliefweb.int/report/world/water-and-sanitation-body-completes-move-unops|title = Water and sanitation body completes move to UNOPS|date = |accessdate = 2015-12-17|website = |publisher = ReliefWeb|last = |first = }} After 2000, WSSCC expanded its work to include advocacy and communications, and began to use the term "[[WASH]]" as an umbrella term for water, sanitation and hygiene from about 2001 onwards''.''Jong, D. de (2003) [http://www.ircwash.org/resources/advocacy-water-environmental-sanitation-and-hygiene Advocacy for water, environmental sanitation and hygiene - Thematic overview paper], IRC, The Netherlands WSSCC's members and staff lobbied for a [[Millennium Development Goal]] target for sanitation, which was adopted at the World Summit on Sustainable Development in 2002 in Johannesburg, South Africa.{{Cite web|url = http://www.who.int/trade/glossary/story097/en/|title = World Summit on Sustainable Development (WSSD)|date = |accessdate = 2015-12-18 |website = |publisher = WHO |last = |first = }} Since 2007, WSSCC has focused on sanitation and hygiene, adding a dedicated sanitation grant financing mechanism (the Global Sanitation Fund) in addition to its networking, knowledge and advocacy work. == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.wsscc.org WSSCC Official website] * [http://wsscc.org/global-sanitation-fund/ Global Sanitation Fund] {{Authority control}} [[Category:United Nations organizations based in Geneva]] [[Category:Sustainability organizations]] [[Category:Water supply]] [[Category:Hygiene]] [[Category:Sanitation]]

overriddenvote2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Wheat Price Guarantee Act''' was a 1919 bill passed by Congress that gave the government the power to regulate the price of wheat.
== Background == At the start of the first World War, the US government passed the [[Lever Food Act|Lever [Food] Act]]. This was done to conserve the food supply and increase its production in order to aid the efforts in Europe during the war. This alone helped food industries, including wheat, to take off. In July 1918, the Grain Corporation (a part of the [[U.S. Food Administration|US Food Administration]]) took on contracts with allied governments, promising to provide as much wheat up to 200 million bushels to the Allied powers. Soon after this, the war ended, and the United States had a decision to make if they were going to honor the wheat prices promised before the war ended. [[File:"They Are Giving All. Will You Send Them Wheat^ U.S. Food Administration.", ca. 1917 - ca. 1919 - NARA - 512442.jpg|left|thumb|260x260px|The US Food Administration used advertisements like this during World War I to urge people to conserve food in order to have enough for the soldiers. Despite the wheat industry being as mobilized as it was, there was always a constant demand for more to aid the war effort.]] During [[World War I]], the wheat industry was mobilized, but following the end of it the demand started to decline, which hurt the still-mobilized agricultural industry. This resulted in the drafting of the Wheat Price Guarantee Act. The [[65th United States Congress|65th Congress]] approved this and it was signed into law by [[Woodrow Wilson]]. The bill appropriated $1,000,000,000 in funds to keep wheat prices constant through the 1919-1920 crop year. The passage of this act allowed the US Government, specifically the President, to monitor wheat prices in order to guarantee farmers profits based on what they had formerly expected to be. The minimum price per bushel was set to $2.26, which is known as a guaranteed price scheme. The passage of this was intended to give the agricultural industry time to adjust to the war being over. The Wheat Price Guarantee Act would officially expire on June 1, 1920. After this, most farmers fell into debt and this laid some of the roots that would lead to the Great Depression in the 30's.
=== Gronna Bill === Senator Gronna attempted to reverse all guarantees within this act with the [[Gronna Bill]]. Many state representatives opposed this, choosing to back the farmers with a 100% guarantee on their profits. The bill did not end up passing in the end.
=== Wheat Prices === The passage of the bill required the US to buy bushels of wheat for at least $2.26 each. Following the expiration of the bill in 1920, prices plummeted back to their typical range of $0.50-$1.50 per bushel. Having lost most of the business they had because of the war, the wheat industry took a big hit. In 1931 during the [[Great Depression]], it would hit a low of just $0.33 per bushel.

{{For|other people with the same name|William Lambert (disambiguation)}} '''William Lambert''' was the Engrosser or Penman of the [[United States Bill of Rights]] whose hand-written copy of the Bill of Rights hangs in the [[National Archives and Records Administration|US National Archives]].
William Lambert served as a congressional clerk at the time of the drafting of the Bill of Rights.
During the 1820s, Lambert was a member of the prestigious society, [[Columbian Institute for the Promotion of Arts and Sciences]], who counted among their members former presidents [[Andrew Jackson]] and [[John Quincy Adams]] and many prominent men of the day, including well-known military representatives, government service persons, medical practitioners, and practitioners of other professions.<ref name="rathbun">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MY-5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA118&lpg=PA118&dq=%22columbian+institute%22&source=bl&ots=norHpKppMQ&sig=Xn1668nfr6y_EhAJVYUcGRBN1pk&hl=en&ei=3jAeTM3mAYHcMaqrjfUM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CCcQ6AEwBzgU#v=onepage&q=%22columbian%20institute%22&f=false |title=The Columbian institute for the promotion of arts and sciences: A Washington Society of 1816-1838. |first=Richard |last=Rathbun |accessdate=2010-06-20|work=|publisher=Bulletin of the United States National Museum, October 18, 1917}}</ref>
==See also== *[[A More Perfect Union (film)]] *[[Constitution Day (United States)]] *[[Constitution of the United States]] *[[History of the United States Constitution]] *[[History of the United States]] *[[National Constitution Center]] *[[United States Bill of Rights]]

'''Womankind Worldwide''' is a UK-based, feminist global women’s rights organisation that works in solidarity with women’s movements around the world to bring about lasting change in women’s lives. Founded in 1989, Womankind partners with women's movements in Africa and Asia to support them in their efforts to change discriminatory laws and policies, challenge gender norms and stereotypes, and provide transformative programmes and services to women and girls.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our impact|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/what-we-do/impact|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
In nearly 30 years, Womankind, together with its partners, has supported over 18 million women and girls across more than 70 countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our impact|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/what-we-do/impact|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
==Background== Founded by [[Sir Alec Reed]], Womankind was launched on [[International Women's Day]] on March 8th, 1989. Kate Young was appointed as Executive Director.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Herstory|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/about-us/history|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref> On March 8th, 2019, the charity will celebrate its 30th anniversary.
==Approach== Womankind does not have staff or offices in the countries where they work - instead, they support existing women's movements to strengthen and grow to support women's rights in their local and national contexts. Womankind does this by providing technical support, communications, connectivity and shared learning, advocacy platforms, and funding opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our approach|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/what-we-do/our-approach|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
Together with their partners, Womankind takes a three-pronged approach, working towards: # Policies and laws that tackle discrimination and protect women, # Universal access to appropriate, quality services that protect and restore women's rights, and # Social change that supports the rights of all women and girls.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our approach|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/what-we-do/our-approach|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
==Aims== Womankind works with its partners in pursuit of three main aims: # An end to all forms of violence against women and girls, # Women's economic rights and control over resources, and # Women's equal influence in decision making and ability to exercise political power.<ref>{{cite web| title=Womankind's aims|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/what-we-do/aims|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
==Focus countries & partners== In 2016-2017, Womankind identified five focus countries on which to focus the majority of their work:<ref>{{cite web|title=Impact Report 2016-17|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/docs/default-source/Annual-Reports/womankind-worldwide-impact-report-2016-17.pdf?sfvrsn=4|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref> * [[Ethiopia]] * [[Kenya]] * [[Nepal]] * [[Uganda]] * [[Zimbabwe]]
=== Ethiopia === In Ethiopia, Womankind works with a number of partners focusing on issues including sexual violence, disabilities, entrepreneurship among women, feminist education, and safe houses and shelters for women escaping violence. For example, they are currently supporting partner [http://www.setaweet.com/ Setaweet] to introduce feminist curriculum to secondary schools in [[Addis Ababa]], Ethiopia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Focus country: Ethiopia|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/where-we-work/ethiopia|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
=== Kenya === Womankind's partners in Kenya work primarily around legal advocacy for women's rights, providing free legal services to women, and lobbying and advocating for women with disabilities. Currently, they are working in long-term partnership with [http://fidakenya.org/ Federation of Women Lawyers - Kenya] to increase women's political participation and access to justice, as well as strengthen community response to early and forced marriage as well as female genital mutilation ([[FGM]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Focus country: Kenya|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/where-we-work/kenya|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
=== Nepal === In Nepal, Womankind supports partners working primarily with [[Dalit]] women, women with disabilities, and indigenous women to enable them to participate in the country's women's movement. Other partners are working or have worked around producing feminist research, guaranteeing the rights of lesbian, bisexual and transgender women, [[gender-based violence]], and women's broader political participation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Focus country: Nepal|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/where-we-work/nepal|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref> For example, Womankind partner [http://www.fedonepal.org/ Feminist Dalit Organization - FEDO] lobbying efforts prior to [[Nepalese local elections, 2017|Nepal's 2017 local elections]] helped result in nearly 7,000 Dalit women being elected to local governments across the country.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clulow|first1=Mike|title=Marginalised women in Nepal are taking their place in local government|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/blog/detail/our-blog/2017/06/19/marginalised-women-in-nepal-are-taking-their-place-in-local-government|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
=== Uganda === Womankind's partners in Uganda work around several issues including gender-based violence, environmental causes, and issues affecting rural women. In March 2018, Womankind and partners [http://nape.or.ug/ National Association of Professional Environmentalists] and [http://nawad.co.ug/ National Association for Women's Action in Development] published [https://www.womankind.org.uk/policy-and-campaigns/resources/digging-deep ''Digging Deep''], a feminist research report revealing the harmful impacts of Uganda's land rush on women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Digging Deep: The impact of Uganda's land rush on women's rights|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/policy-and-campaigns/resources/digging-deep|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
=== Zimbabwe === In Zimbabwe, Womankind is supporting partners in strengthening civil society prior to the 2018 general elections, supporting feminist research and documentation in the countries, increasing the voices of lesbian, bisexual and transgender women, supporting women with disabilities, and advocating for improved access to justice, among other issues. For example, through Womankind's partnership with [http://www.zwla.co.zw/ Zimbabwe Women Lawyers Association], the organization provides legal services to women for cases on domestic violence, divorce, land and property disputes, and child support.<ref>{{cite web|title=Focus country: Zimbabwe|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/where-we-work/zimbabwe|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
=== Other countries === In addition, the charity continues to work with partners in [[Afghanistan]], [[Bolivia]], [[Ghana]], [[Liberia]], [[Peru]], [[Sierra Leone]], [[Tanzania]], and [[Zambia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Our partners|url=https://www.womankind.org.uk/what-we-do/our-approach/partners|website=Womankind Worldwide}}</ref>
==Media & campaigns== Womankind is active on social media, including on [https://twitter.com/woman_kind Twitter], [https://www.facebook.com/Womankind Facebook], and [https://www.instagram.com/womankindworldwide/ Instagram]. Their website also hosts an active [https://www.womankind.org.uk/blog blog], as well as [https://www.womankind.org.uk/what-we-do/stories case studies] featuring women impacted by Womankind's partners. In the media, Womankind has been featured in the [https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/justice-for-women-is-key-to-ending-violence_uk_5a18012ee4b0bf1467a8460a Huffington Post], [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/long_reads/uganda-land-grabs-rush-woman-evictions-farm-labour-international-womens-day-a8242626.html the Independent], and [https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/nov/25/gender-inequality-domestic-violence-womankind-worldwide the Guardian].
The organization is also active in advocacy and campaigning efforts, partaking in annual campaigns for [[16 Days of Activism]] as well as [[International Women's Day]].

{{bots|deny=Monkbot6}}<!-- keep Monkbot task 6 from visiting this page --> [[File:Cumbre Iberoamericana 2007.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Ibero-American Summit, 2007: Juan Carlos, Zapatero and Chávez are seated on the right side of the chamber. (Chávez is seated at the table in the bottom-right corner clapping.)]] {{italic title}} '''''¿Por qué no te callas?''''' ({{IPA-es|poɾˈke no te ˈkaʎas}}, English: "Why don't you shut up?") is a phrase that was uttered by [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|King Juan Carlos I]] of [[Spain]] to [[Venezuela]]n President [[Hugo Chávez]], at the 2007 [[Ibero-American Summit]] in [[Santiago, Chile]], when Chávez was repeatedly interrupting Prime Minister of Spain [[José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero]]'s speech. The phrase became an overnight sensation, gaining [[Cult following|cult status]] as a mobile-phone [[ringtone]]; spawning a [[domain name]]; a contest; T-shirt sales; a television program; and [[YouTube]] videos.
== Incident == At the meeting on 10 November 2007, Chávez repeatedly interrupted Zapatero to call Zapatero's predecessor, [[José María Aznar]], a "fascist" and "less human than snakes",<ref name=ShutUpBBC>{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7089131.stm |title = Shut up, Spain king tells Chavez |date = 10 November 2007 |publisher = [[BBC]] |accessdate = 9 November 2007 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071111194305/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7089131.stm |archivedate = 11 November 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> and accuse Aznar of having supported a [[2002 Venezuelan coup d'état attempt|failed coup d'état aimed at removing Chávez from power]]. Zapatero had earlier irritated Chávez by suggesting that Latin America needed to attract more [[foreign portfolio investment|foreign capital]] to combat its "chronic, deepening poverty", and claimed that Chávez's policies scared investors out of Latin America.<ref name=ShutUpBBC /><ref name=TimeRebuke>{{cite news|author=Padgett, Tim|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1682967,00.html?imw=Y|title=Behind the King's Rebuke to Chávez|accessdate=14 November 2007|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=12 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115094835/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1682967,00.html?imw=Y|archivedate=15 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Chávez's attacks became so strong that Zapatero rose to Aznar's defence, even though he had been severely critical of Aznar in the past. Zapatero pointed out that Aznar had been democratically elected and was "a legitimate representative of the Spanish people".<ref name=ShutUpBBC />
Although organizers switched off Chávez's microphone, he continued to interrupt as Zapatero defended Aznar. Juan Carlos leaned forward, turned towards his fellow head of state, and said, "''¿Por qué no te callas?''" The king's rebuke received applause from the general audience.<ref name=TimeRebuke /> He addressed Chávez using the [[T–V distinction|familiar form of "you"]]. (In Spanish, ''tú'' and ''te'' are usually used in informal chat, among young people or when addressing close friends, family, or children, and can be perceived as insulting when used in other circumstances.)<ref name=ShutUpBBC /> Shortly thereafter, he left the hall, when Nicaraguan President [[Daniel Ortega]] accused Spain of intervention in his country's elections and complained about the presence of Spanish energy companies in Nicaragua.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite web|url=http://www.antena3.com/a3noticias/servlet/Noticias?destino=../a3n/noticia/noticia.jsp&sidicom=si&id=13286798|title=El Rey Don Juan Carlos a Hugo Chávez: "''¿Por qué no te callas?''"|accessdate=11 November 2007|publisher=[[Antena 3 (Spain)|Antena 3]]|date=11 November 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112090430/http://www.antena3.com/a3noticias/servlet/Noticias?destino=..%2Fa3n%2Fnoticia%2Fnoticia.jsp&sidicom=si&id=13286798|archivedate=12 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The incident was unprecedented, as never before had the king displayed such anger in public.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elperiodico.com/default.asp?idpublicacio_PK=46&idioma=CAS&idnoticia_PK=457570&idseccio_PK=1007 |title=Nunca se había visto al Rey tan enfadado en público |author=Tabar, Carmen |publisher=El Periódico de Catalunya |date=10 November 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208073548/http://www.elperiodico.com/default.asp?idpublicacio_PK=46&idioma=CAS&idnoticia_PK=457570&idseccio_PK=1007 |archivedate=8 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
For the king, the incident was part of an ''[[Annus horribilis#Juan Carlos I of Spain|annus horribilis]]'' for the royal image, according to the Chilean newspaper ''[[La Nación (Chile)|La Nación]]''.<ref name="La Nación">{{es icon}} {{cite news | url = http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias_v2/site/artic/20071115/pags/20071115203346.html | title = El 'annus horribilis' del Rey Juan Carlos | publisher = [[La Nación (Chile)]] | date = 15 November 2007 | accessdate = 17 February 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20121206025748/http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias_v2/site/artic/20071115/pags/20071115203346.html | archivedate = 6 December 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
''[[The New York Times]]'' analyzed the incident, arguing that it exposed "the unendingly complicated relations between Spain and [[Spanish Empire|its former colonies]]".<ref name="Colonies">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/25/weekinreview/25romero.html|work=The New York Times|author=Romero, Simon|date=25 November 2007|title=When a Mother Country Tells Its Kid, 'Shut Up'|accessdate=26 February 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215071736/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/25/weekinreview/25romero.html|archivedate=15 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Reaction == After the events at the summit, Hugo Chávez made statements against King Juan Carlos I, questioning his democratic [[Legitimacy (political science)|legitimacy]], and whether he knew about and endorsed the attempted coup d'état in Venezuela in 2002. Chávez defended his accusations against Aznar, arguing that prohibiting criticism of an elected official such as Aznar would be similar to prohibiting criticism of Hitler. He stated that he would revise Venezuela's position towards Spain and increase surveillance of the activities of Spanish companies in Venezuela, where Spain had been the main investor and trade partner in the last decade.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite web |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Chavez/carga/Rey/avisa/revisara/relaciones/Espana/elpepiesp/20071115elpepinac_2/Tes |work=El País |title=Chávez carga contra el Rey y avisa de que revisará las relaciones con España |date=15 November 2007 |accessdate=15 November 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725171522/http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Chavez/carga/Rey/avisa/revisara/relaciones/Espana/elpepiesp/20071115elpepinac_2/Tes |archivedate=25 July 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Spanish government showed appreciation for the reaction of the king and for Zapatero's defense of the dignity of Spanish elected representatives like Aznar.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Moratinos/afirma/ultimo/debe/hacerse/llamar/embajador/consultas/elpepuesp/20071115elpepunac_3/Tes|work=El País|title=Moratinos afirma que "lo último que debe hacerse" es llamar al embajador a consultas|date=15 November 2007|accessdate=15 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016143632/http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Moratinos/afirma/ultimo/debe/hacerse/llamar/embajador/consultas/elpepuesp/20071115elpepunac_3/Tes|archivedate=16 October 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Several days after the event, Chávez demanded an apology from King Juan Carlos and warned Spain that he would review diplomatic ties and take action against Spanish investments such as [[Grupo Santander|Banco Santander]] and [[Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria]] in Venezuela.<ref name=ReconsiderTies /> He accused the king of displaying the kind of Spanish arrogance that led to Spain's ejection from South America at the hands of Venezuela's hero, [[Simón Bolívar]].<ref name=ReconsiderTies>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/15/world/americas/15venez.html?ref=world|title=Chávez Threatens to Reconsider Venezuela's Ties With Spain|agency=Reuters|work=The New York Times|date=15 November 2007|accessdate=16 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101110226/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/15/world/americas/15venez.html?ref=world|archivedate=1 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Spanish diplomats were concerned that Chávez may replace his socialism and attacks on "American Imperialism" with attacks on what he called "Spanish imperialism".<ref name=FTConquer /> Speaking about Venezuela's indigenous peoples, Chávez said of the Spanish, "They slit our people's throats and chopped them into little bits and left them on the outskirts of towns and villages – that was what the Spanish empire did here".<ref name=FTConquer /> The Spanish foreign ministry denied that the ''"¿Por qué no te callas?"'' incident was indicative of Spanish–Latin American relations.<ref name=FTConquer /> Some analysts say Chávez used such incidents to "fire up his support base among the majority poor at home with blunt language that played on their misgivings of rich countries' investments in Latin America".<ref name=ReconsiderTies />
According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', it is uncertain which of the two men came out of the incident looking worse: "Chávez for his boorish lack of etiquette",<ref name=BattleRoyal /> or the king for insulting another leader. The king's words raised questions as the "200th anniversary of independence for the former Spanish colonies" approached.<ref name=BattleRoyal /> Several days after the incident, Venezuela's state-run television ran footage of Juan Carlos with [[Francisco Franco]]. The king was depicted as the dictator's lackey; but the fact that the [[Spanish Constitution of 1978]], which preserved the monarchy, had been approved by a referendum; and the key role played by the king in putting down an [[23-F|attempted military coup in 1981]], were not mentioned.<ref name=BattleRoyal />
The king's outburst received divided reactions from other leaders. Brazil's President [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]] defended Chávez, while Peru's and El Salvador's presidents [[Alan García]] and [[Antonio Saca]] supported the king.<ref name=BattleRoyal />
An editor for the ''[[Washington Post]]'' noted the "Spanish-speaking world has been abuzz about [this] verbal slapdown" and suggested that King Juan Carlos "should have asked the assembled heads of state: 'Why don't you speak up?'"<ref>Jackson Diehl, "Silencing Venezuela's President a Royal Task", 21 November 2007, syndicated in the ''[[Albuquerque Journal]]'', p. A9.</ref>
== Aftermath ==
=== Immediate === One week after the event, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' wrote that King [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia]] delivered a second rebuke in one week to Chávez from a king, when he reminded Chávez that oil should not be used as a tool for conflict. The remarks came minutes after Chávez called for [[OPEC]] to "assert itself as an active political agent" at the OPEC summit in Saudi Arabia's capital, Riyadh.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119532579754096997?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Chavez's OPEC Speech Spurs Rebuke From Saudi King|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=17 November 2007|accessdate=20 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507100343/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119532579754096997?mod=googlenews_wsj|archivedate=7 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In a followup at the OPEC summit, ''[[Reuters]]'' wrote that "Spain's king cannot shut Chavez up but bladder can",<ref name=Bladder>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUKN1947231020071119|title=Spain's king cannot shut Chavez up but bladder can|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=19 November 2007|accessdate=20 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121110634/http://uk.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUKN1947231020071119|archivedate=21 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and that Chávez said to a throng of reporters at the OPEC summit, "For a while now, I have needed to go to the bathroom and I am going to pee ... Do you want me to pee on you?"<ref name=Bladder />
Two weeks after the event, Chile's President [[Michelle Bachelet]] revealed that she had politely requested that Chávez abstain from making some statements at the summit, indicating frankly that she felt "let down" by the subsequent discussions at the OPEC meeting, considering the effect that the price of oil has on countries like Chile.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercopress.com/vernoticia.do?id=11957&formato=HTML|title=Bachelet also asked Chavez, (politely) to shut up|publisher=MercoPress|date=23 November 2007|accessdate=23 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071127141358/http://www.mercopress.com/vernoticia.do?id=11957&formato=html|archivedate=27 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Also just weeks after the incident, Chávez was "accused of breaking a protocol accord" with Colombia's [[Álvaro Uribe Vélez|President Álvaro Uribe]] and "exhaust[ing] his Colombian counterpart's patience by speaking out of turn once too often", formally ending Chávez's mediation in hostage negotiations with the Colombian [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia]] (FARC) guerrilla group.<ref>{{cite news|author=Hudson, Saul|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/politicsNews/idUSN2224925520071122?sp=true|title=Colombian mediation failure hurts talkative Chavez|agency=Reuters|date=22 November 2007|accessdate=23 November 2007}}</ref> (Dialogue resumed later and the hostages were freed in January 2008.)
=== Enduring === In 2013, Infobae named the incident among those most noted to have captured public attention in the history of the Ibero-American Summit.<ref>{{es}} {{cite web |url= http://www.infobae.com/2013/10/18/1517127-cumbre-papelones-del-por-que-no-te-callas-al-intercambio-corbatas-aznar-y-fidel |title= Cumbre de papelones: del "¿por qué no te callas?" al intercambio de corbatas entre Aznar y Fidel |date= 18 October 2013 |accessdate= 14 November 2013 |publisher= infobae |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131024222814/http://www.infobae.com/2013/10/18/1517127-cumbre-papelones-del-por-que-no-te-callas-al-intercambio-corbatas-aznar-y-fidel |archivedate= 24 October 2013 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> ''Entorno Inteligente'' invoked the phrase, paying homage to Spain for the "immortal lexicon", and referring to Venezuelan politician [[Nicolás Maduro]] as ''inmaduro'' (immature).<ref>{{es}} {{cite web |url= http://www.entornointeligente.com/articulo/1572136/Por-que-no-te-callas-inMaduro-02112013 |date= 2 November 2013 |accessdate= 14 November 2013 |title= ¿Por qué no te callas, in−Maduro? |publisher= Entorno Inteligente |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140714201518/http://www.entornointeligente.com/articulo/1572136/Por-que-no-te-callas-inMaduro-02112013 |archivedate= 14 July 2014 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Analitica.com said that language used at the 2013 Summit should be clear, and that the rebuke of Chávez is still remembered.<ref>{{es}} {{cite web |url= http://www.analitica.com/va/internacionales/opinion/1054388.asp |publisher=Analitica.com |title= Cumbres Iberoamericanas: Pasado y Futuro |author= [[Milos Alcalay]] |date= 29 October 2013 |accessdate= 14 November 2013}}</ref>
== Popularity of phrase == Zapatero said he did not realize what an influential moment it had been until he returned home and his eldest daughter greeted him with ''"¿Por qué no te callas?"'', which made them both laugh.<ref>{{es icon}} Hermoso, Borja. {{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Aznar/Zapatero/eres/presidente/llamas/quieras/elpepuesp/20071113elpepunac_23/Tes|title=Aznar a Zapatero: "Tú eres el presidente, me llamas cuando quieras".|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520050307/http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Aznar/Zapatero/eres/presidente/llamas/quieras/elpepuesp/20071113elpepunac_23/Tes|archivedate=20 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} ''El País'', 13 November 2007. . Retrieved 15 November 2007.</ref>
The king's phrase gained cult slogan status, ringing from mobile phones; appearing on [[T-shirt]]s; and being used as a greeting. The domain, porquenotecallas.com, had reached US$4,600 on eBay as of 16 November 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cellular-news.com/story/27491.php|title=Regal 'Shut Up' Becomes a Cult Ringtone|date=16 November 2007|publisher=cellular-news.com|accessdate=16 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117034044/http://www.cellular-news.com/story/27491.php|archivedate=17 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=Corral /> The phrase became a YouTube sensation overnight and a song was written to a traditional tune.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/11/15/AR2007111501455.html|title='Why Don't You Shut Up?' Chavez's antagonistic antics have their limit|author=Sanchez, Marcela|work=The Washington Post|date=16 November 2007|accessdate=16 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820074539/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/11/15/AR2007111501455.html|archivedate=20 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The phrase has spawned countless media articles, jokes, songs and video clips; while in Spain an estimated 500,000 people downloaded the phrase as a ringtone, generating €1.5 million (US$2 million) in sales.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7101386.stm 'Shut up' Chavez is ringtone hit.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121110534/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7101386.stm |date=21 November 2007 }} BBC News, 19 November 2007. . Retrieved 19 November 2007.</ref><ref name=Nadie>{{es icon}} [http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/spanish/latin_america/newsid_7095000/7095670.stm Ahora nadie se calla.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116085842/http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/spanish/latin_america/newsid_7095000/7095670.stm |date=16 November 2007 }} BBC Mundo, 14 November 2007. . Retrieved 15 November 2007.</ref> As of 14 November 2007, Google generated 665,000 webhits on the phrase and YouTube had 610 videos.<ref name=Nadie /> Entrepreneurs in Florida and Texas put the slogan on T-shirts, and marketed them on [[eBay]] and elsewhere;<ref name="Colonies" /> the phrase became a greeting among Venezuelan expats in Miami and Spain<ref name=Corral>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2004017429_ringtone16.html|title=Spanish king's retort to Chávez strikes chord|author=Corral, Oscar|date=13 November 2007|work=The Seattle Times|accessdate=16 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071122152938/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2004017429_ringtone16.html|archivedate=22 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and a slogan for Chávez opponents.<ref name=FTConquer>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21822492/|title=Juan Carlos' words conquer the net|work= Financial Times |author=Crawford, Leslie Crawford |date=15 November 2007|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=16 November 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071117205413/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21822492/ <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 17 November 2007}}</ref><ref name=Kingrow>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/talking_point/7096950.stm Viewpoints: Chavez and King row.] BBC News, 16 November 2007. . Retrieved 17 November 2007.</ref>
Less than 24 hours after the event, the king's words were used by sports commentators during the radio transmission of Spanish language football games to describe controversial events. A contest for the best audiovisual depiction of the event was announced in Spain.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|url=http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2007/11/13/cyt_ava_tono-de-la-frase-p_13A1191237.shtml|title=Tono de la frase "¿por qué no te callas?" arrasa en politonías de celulares|work=[[El Universal (Caracas)|El Universal]]|date=16 November 2007|accessdate=16 November 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924001929/http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2007/11/13/cyt_ava_tono-de-la-frase-p_13A1191237.shtml |archivedate=24 September 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'' editorial page suggested that the phrase would have the power to change the course of history, as has been credited to [[Ronald Reagan]]'s, "Mr. Gorbachev, [[tear down this wall!]]"<ref>{{cite news|title=Royal message to petty dictator: Just shut up|last=Cooklis|first=Ray|work=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]|location=Cincinnati, Ohio|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|page=8B|date=23 November 2007|accessdate=23 November 2007|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CEQB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11D5A7BEB47FB668&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|subscription=yes|quote=History provides us with many examples of famous catch-phrases – the right words, uttered at just the right time – that have shown the power to change the course of events: ... Reagan's 'Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall.' Someday soon, we may be able to add to this list the blunt suggestion, already a hot Internet buzz-phrase and cell-phone ring tone, by an exasperated King Juan Carlos I to Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez during a recent summit in Chile: "Why don't you shut up?"|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026154535/http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004|archivedate=26 October 2008|df=dmy-all}}<!-- http://news.enquirer.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071123/EDIT01/711230358/1090/EDIT --></ref>
The ''Los Angeles Times'' said "the Spanish-speaking world can hardly stop talking about [the incident]", which provided "fodder for satirists from Mexico City to Madrid".<ref name=BattleRoyal /> The reaction was apparent "in newspaper headlines, cable television and on YouTube. His phrase was reproduced on T-shirts, and cellphone ring tones. In Mexico City, the dust-up became a satirical skit, "El Chabo del 8".<!-- It's SATIRE, PARODY, not the real show! Please leave the typo! --> In El Salvador's capital, the phrase became a playful greeting".<ref name=BattleRoyal>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-chavez17nov17,1,7510496.story?coll=la-headlines-world|title=King's words to Chavez start a battle royal|work=Los Angeles Times|author=Kraul, Chris|date=17 November 2007|accessdate=17 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206160526/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-chavez17nov17,1,7510496.story?coll=la-headlines-world|archivedate=6 February 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In Australia ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' reported the king could earn a multimillion-euro business if he claimed rights over the phrase, which generated a ''[[Benny Hill Show]]''-style skit and a Nike ad, "Juan do it. Just shut up", with the Brazilian football star, [[Ronaldinho]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/why-dont-you-shut-up/2007/11/19/1195321697277.html|title=Royal outburst now a nasty little earner|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=20 November 2007|accessdate=20 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120215037/http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/why-dont-you-shut-up/2007/11/19/1195321697277.html|archivedate=20 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Canada's ''[[CBC News]]'' said an actor's voice was used to mimic the king's voice in the ringtone to avoid legal problems over the use of the phrase, which also generated sales of coffee mugs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2007/11/19/spain-ringtone.html|title='King of Spain' tells half a million callers to 'shut up': New, insulting ringtone a smash hit in Spain|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=19 November 2007|accessdate=20 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071122183800/http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2007/11/19/spain-ringtone.html|archivedate=22 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The infamous phrase was also referred to in a comic song called "[[Baila el Chiki-chiki]]", Spain's contribution to [[Eurovision 2008]], and in the song "La Plata", by the Brazilian band [[Jota Quest]].
Protestors against the Chávez government adopted the phrase as their slogan;<ref name=Kingrow /> T-shirts in Venezuela had the slogan with the "NO" in capital letters, representing a call to vote against amendments in the [[Venezuelan constitutional referendum, 2007|December 2007 constitutional referendum]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsvine.com/_news/2007/11/19/1108819-shut-up-is-hit-ringtone-in-spain|title=NBC News - Breaking News & Top Stories - Latest World, US & Local News|author=|date=|website=newsvine.com|accessdate=7 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026045539/http://www.newsvine.com/_news/2007/11/19/1108819-shut-up-is-hit-ringtone-in-spain|archivedate=26 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the phrase was used as a taunt when more than 100,000 marched in protest against Chávez's proposed constitutional changes.<ref name="MarchTaunt">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article2976631.ece|work=The Times|date=30 November 2007|title=100,000 march against Hugo Chavez reforms|accessdate=30 November 2007|location=London|first1=Hannah|last1=Strange|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706165434/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article2976631.ece|archivedate=6 July 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In Argentina, a television program called ''Por qué no te callas'' began broadcasting on 6 December 2007.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite web|url=http://www.laflecha.net/canales/comunicacion/noticias/el-por-que-no-te-callas-del-rey-juan-carlos-i-en-la-tv-argentina/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071207183842/http://www.laflecha.net/canales/comunicacion/noticias/el-por-que-no-te-callas-del-rey-juan-carlos-i-en-la-tv-argentina|dead-url=yes|archive-date=7 December 2007|title=El "¿por qué no te callas?" del rey Juan Carlos I, en la TV argentina|work=La Flecha|date=5 December 2007|accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> The phrase was also seen at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://caracas.eluniversal.com/sudafrica10/2010/06/21/sur10_ava_frase-por-que-no-t_21A4063571.shtml |title=Frase "¿Por qué no te callas?" aparece en el España – Honduras |date=21 June 2010 |work=[[El Universal (Caracas)|El Universal]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100624101012/http://caracas.eluniversal.com/sudafrica10/2010/06/21/sur10_ava_frase-por-que-no-t_21A4063571.shtml |archivedate=24 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In Colombia, a famous YouTube animation called "Vulgarcito" depicted a summit between some Latin American countries and since Hugo Chávez never stopped talking in the animation, Vulgarcito, the main character, slapped him and shouted "Shhh. It is time to quote the wise King of Spain and ask you: Why don't you shut up?"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JY06ySAnoKw|title=VULGARCITO vs CHAVEZ (original en HQ)|first=|last=cardoto|date=16 December 2009|publisher=|accessdate=7 May 2018|via=YouTube|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531231747/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JY06ySAnoKw|archivedate=31 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Alternative forms == According to ''[[Foundation of Urgent Spanish|Fundéu BBVA]]'', the Urgent Spanish Foundation,<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite web|title=¡Por qué no te callas!|url=http://www.fundeu.es/Consultas.aspx?frmOpcion=CONSULTA&frmFontSize=2&frmIdConsulta=690|work=Fundéu|accessdate=20 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216015604/http://www.fundeu.es/Consultas.aspx?frmOpcion=CONSULTA&frmFontSize=2&frmIdConsulta=690|archivedate=16 December 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the Director of the [[Academia Chilena de la Lengua|Chilean Academy of the Spanish language]],<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite web|title=En chileno la frase del rey Juan Carlos sería: ¡por qué no te callái vo!|url=http://www.lun.com/modulos/catalogo/paginas/2007/11/19/LUCPRDI02LU1911.htm?tipoPantalla=1024|work=[[Las Últimas Noticias]]|date=19 November 2007|accessdate=20 November 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071121104137/http://www.lun.com/modulos/catalogo/paginas/2007/11/19/LUCPRDI02LU1911.htm?tipoPantalla=1024 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 21 November 2007}}</ref> the phrase uttered by the king, given the situation under which it was said, should be written with exclamation marks instead of question marks: ''¡Por qué no te callas!'' Alternatively, it could be written using a combination of both exclamation and question marks: ''¡¿Por qué no te callas?!'' or ''¿¡Por qué no te callas!?''
